snippet: Reader stories from around New York City, including an in-demand parking spot and a facetious announcement on an airplane.

headline.main: Driving Through a Downturn and Other Reader Tales
headline.print_headline: Driving Through a Downturn and Other Reader Tales

snippet: Governments reports will include retail sales for January and business inventories for December, and companies reporting earnings will include Avon, Deere, General Motors, Molson Coors and Zynga.

headline.main: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead

snippet: Path, the mobile social network, has apologized for mining personal data, but the privacy violation is yet another indication of Silicon Valley’s lack of concern about its protection of customers and their personal data.
abstract: Path, the mobile social network, has apologized for mining personal data, but the privacy violation is yet another indication of Silicon Valley’s lack of concern about its protection of customers and their personal data.

headline.main: Disruptions: So Many Apologies, So Much Data Mining
headline.print_headline: Disruptions: So Many Apologies, So Much Data Mining

snippet: Path, the mobile social network, has apologized for mining personal data, but it is yet one more public demonstration of Silicon Valley's lack of concern about the privacy of its customers and the protection of their personal data. Even more telli...
abstract: Path, the mobile social network, has apologized for mining personal data, but it is yet one more public demonstration of Silicon Valley's lack of concern about the privacy of its customers and the protection of their personal data. Even more telling was the Valley's reaction to the apology.

headline.main: Disruptions: So Many Apologies, So Much Data Mining

snippet: Tim Bucher of TastingRoom.com says he holds weekly dinners to talk about the big picture at his company. “There are no computers at dinner,” he says. “There are no interruptions.”
abstract: Adam Bryant Corner Office column features interview with TastingRoom.com founder and chief executive officer Tim Bucher discussing his management technique.

snippet: Leonard Cohen is not the only musician with a fan base that spans decades.
abstract: Jesse Kornbluth Loose Ends column marvels at the fact that Leonard Cohen's latest album occupied the No. 1 position on Amazon.com for a week; notes that, at age 77, Cohen has plenty of company among older musicians still reaching the top of the charts.

snippet: Readers debate whether a new primary and voting system proposed by a letter writer would improve how we elect a president.
abstract: Sunday Dialogue on whether the primary and voting system in the United States should be changed to improve the way Americans elect a president.

headline.main: Sunday Dialogue: Rethinking How We Vote
headline.print_headline: Sunday Dialogue: Rethinking How We Vote

snippet: Books on Carl Van Vechten, a white writer who had a passion for blackness, on a woman’s rejection of her Hasidic roots and on New York architecture.
abstract: Sam Roberts reviews books Carl Van Vechten and the Harlem Renaissance: A Portrait in Black and White by Emily Bernard, Unorthodox: The Scandalous Rejection of My Hasidic Roots by Deborah Feldman, How to Read New York: A Crash Course in Big Apple Architecture by Will Jones and Guide to Contemporary New York City Architecture by John Hill.

headline.main: Embracing a Race and Rejecting a Sect
headline.print_headline: Embracing a Race and Rejecting a Sect

snippet: Last week, Arun Thampi, a programmer in Singapore, discovered that the mobile social network Path was surreptitiously copying  address book information from users' iPhones without notifying them.     David Morin, Path's voluble chief executive, qu...
abstract: Nick Bilton Disruptions column on the mobile social network Path, which had been copying address book information from users' iPhones without notifying them; statements by Path's chief executive David Morin leads some to think he is unconcerned about the privacy and safety concerns that could result from Path's actions. (M)2

headline.main: Disruptions: So Many Apologies, So Much Data Mining

snippet: Research in Motion can't catch a break. Joining the large crop of businesses and organizations dropping the BlackBerry, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration plans to provide employees with Apple's iPhones and iPads instead.     The ...
abstract: Bits blog; Research in Motion continues to struggle as another large client, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, announces plans to provide employees with Apple's iPhones and iPads instead of BlackBerry devices. (M)3

headline.main: BlackBerry Loses Another Big Client To the iPhone
